newsitem.title: USA: Private projects boost U.S. Jan building activity.
newsitem.headline: Private projects boost U.S. Jan building activity.

text.p: Spending on new construction increased modestly in January, the Commerce Department said on Monday, as builders shook off the impact of bad weather that slowed activity in December.

Spending increased 0.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $589.8 billion. That followed a revised 0.9 percent decline in December instead of the 0.7 percent drop the department previously reported.
Storms and flooding in December, especially in the West, slowed down many building projects but January weather was less extreme.
January construction activity was stronger than anticipated by Wall Street economists who had forecast spending would be unchanged from December.
All the gain came in privately financed projects, where spending increased 0.5 percent to a record $445.7 billion after declining 0.3 percent in December.

Spending on new homes and apartments was up 0.4 percent in January to $249.7 billion a year after a slim 0.2 percent december gain. For nonresidential buildings like offices and hotels, January construction spending increased 2.9 percent to $153.8 billion after dropping 3 percent in December.

Government spending on construction projects was flat in January at an annual rate of $144.1 billion. Spending fell on contruction of water supply plants, sewers and new housing projects in January but was up for schools, hospitals and other public buildings.
After allowing for inflation, total construction spending was up 0.5 percent in January to a seasonally adjusted $506.7 billion annual rate after a 1.1 percent drop in December, the department said.
